Getting Started with Siconos

Introduction

Siconos is a free (GNU license) software, dedicated to modeling, simulation and control of Non Smooth Dynamical Systems.

Useful links:

  • Siconos Home Page.
  • Siconos Download.
  • Siconos Help and Documentation.

Aim of this document

This manual aims at giving user a short overview of the software functionnalities. It is also supposed to provide some guidelines on how to build its own simulation.
However, this manual does not give a full description of all the classes, functions etc of Siconos. For this, you need to check directly in the Siconos Doxygen Documentation.
You can also check on Related Pages tab on top of page for some other detailed documentations.

  • Describing a Non Smooth Problem with Siconos

  • Preliminaries

  • Running a simulation

  • Siconos Tutorial (C++)

  • Using XML

  • Using Python interface

  • How to use this guide?

Running a simulation

There are two different ways to run a simulation with Siconos: directly with a C++ input file or thanks to a specific interface, with Python or Scilab.

With a C++ input file
First check that Siconos is well installed (see Siconos Installation Guide).
Create a directory for your example, where the following files must be present:

  • the main input cpp file
  • all the xxxPlugin.cpp files necessary for your simulation (for details on plug-in see Siconos Plug-in Functions)
  • the xml input file if you use xml data description

Then just run: 

siconos myInputFile.cpp
The simulation will then start. Note that xxxPlugin.so and an executable, myInputFile.out are created in the current directory.

To clean up the directory: 

siconos -c

For verbose mode when running, add "-v" option to siconos.

Note: if siconos is not installed in the default, search path, you may have to give a full path name, that is SICONOS_INSTALL_DIRECTORY_NAME/siconos.
Or just change your PATH variable: 

setenv PATH $PATH:SICONOS_INSTALL_DIRECTORY_NAME
or
PATH=$PATH:SICONOS_INSTALL_DIRECTORY_NAME
export PATH

With Front-End (Scilab or Python)
First check that Siconos and Siconos Front-End are well installed.
About Scilab and Python installation see Prerequisite.

With Python: 

pySiconos myInputFile.py

With Scilab 

scilab -f myInputFile.sci

How to use this guide?

For each topic, we first give a list of the concerned classes. This should help you to find the required header files and to access to more detailed documentation in the Doxygen.
Then we describe the more common way to build objects (ie the constructors) and give a list of the more useful functions.
